feed.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT

entry.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT
entry.summary:
The discussion between Johnson Lau and Rusty Russell revolves around the complexities and safety concerns associated with committing to a subset of the script in each signature within blockchain technology, particularly in contexts such as lightning/eltoo networks. The core of their debate lies in balancing the trade-off between reducing complexity in transactions and ensuring the safety of funds. Russell points out a common crypto anti-pattern: assuming a system is secure simply because one cannot find a way to break it, despite others' reservations. This approach is critiqued in the context of evaluating the safety and practicality of script masking versus the "NOINPUT" flag in cryptocurrency transactions.
Russell elaborates on the feasibility and potential benefits of script masking, arguing that it offers a general enough solution to prevent common mistakes (referred to as "footguns") without overly restricting the functionality of scripts. He provides an example where script masking could allow for specific channel identifiers and state numbers to be included within a transaction script, ensuring that signatures are only valid for their intended channel, even in cases where channels might otherwise share key attributes like capacity and keys. This specificity could significantly reduce the risk of erroneous transactions across different channels.
In contrast, the "NOINPUT" option is criticized for committing to dangerously little context, making it less safe as a primitive function within transaction scripts. Russell suggests that the inclusion of "_UNSAFE" or a similar warning in its name might reflect its risky nature. Despite his openness to accepting some level of risk, Russell expresses reservations about supporting "NOINPUT" due to these safety concerns. He concludes by affirming that committing to a masked script not only enhances security but could also simplify the creation of safer transaction protocols, viewing this approach as a significant improvement over more minimalistic methods.
